website_summaries.verdict: Pre-seasoned cast iron construction takes much of the work out of pressing tortillas. Some consider the Victoria to be the Cadillac of tortilla presses, but be aware of its additional weight. Naturally non-stick.
pros: Heavy cast iron lid makes pressing easier
cons: Top plate and handle can break

customer_reviews.title: Great High Quality Press!!
customer_reviews.text: Very high quality tortilla press. It does take practice however to use the press in the same way that you need to practice rolling out pie dough. You need to use a plastic ziploc bag over the press to keep the dough from sticking and you cannot roll out the dough too thin. Also the dough must have the perfect consistency which you can learn from any Mexican Chef! : )
customer_reviews.author: QueenAmazon

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Makes really good roti! I followed the instructions in one of the review. Press 2-3 times for desired thickness.
customer_reviews.author: Gautam Chauhan

customer_reviews.title: Poorly made
customer_reviews.text: This broke the first time I used it. The arm snapped right off! I'm not talking about the pin but the arm itself! I would like a replacement item or refund, but the option isn't available in my account.
customer_reviews.author: Midge

customer_reviews.title: Severely disappointed as I just missed my return
customer_reviews.text: Just opened and used press and literallly on the first tortilla I made the handle broke off. Severely disappointed as I just missed my return window
customer_reviews.author: Kyle A.

customer_reviews.title: No more store bought.
customer_reviews.text: Very satisfied. I had been being cheap and doing tortillas by hand and rolling pin. You should put the dough slightly off center so it doesn't come out the side, or use a smaller dough ball. I would order again. Also, let the weight of the cast iron flatten the dough, not much strength needed to get the job done. Cast iron will shear if too much weight applied to the handle, although it's seems better built than it was in the picture of it broken. Remember it's not like steel. Enjoy!
customer_reviews.author: Shannon

customer_reviews.title: First time use and broke!
customer_reviews.text: Just used this Tortilla Press the first time and the Hinge from the Handle already broke off! I didn't even press down that hard and the pieces flew and just barely missed my Eye! Returning it for a Refund and buy at a Physical Store!!!
customer_reviews.author: C. M.

customer_reviews.title: No quality control
customer_reviews.text: Really??!!! The tab to hold the pin for handle has no hole in it So DISSAPOINTED
customer_reviews.author: Pz14559

customer_reviews.title: Not constructed well.
customer_reviews.text: I eat a lot of tortillas and have begun making them at home, so I had hoped that this would make the process a bit easier. However, the design requires more strength and leverage to get a flat tortilla than it is able to handle. I'm glad nobody got hurt, I'm seeing that many others are experiencing broken handles and parts while trying to achieve a god flat tortilla.
customer_reviews.author: Trianine

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: Broke on my first press of a tortilla. It seemed heavy duty
customer_reviews.author: Whitney

customer_reviews.title: It cant be real cast iron! It split in half!
customer_reviews.text: If I could give it negative stars then I truly would. I am a petite and slim woman and while I was pressing a dough ball, this thing split in half! I was using gluten free flour and I was not trying to press a rock but a soft dough and still it did this. I wish I could return this and get my money back. I'm glad that it didn't fall on my foot or something but the way it's split is truly shocking. I've never known cast iron to split like this. I'm utterly disappointed!
customer_reviews.author: farah

customer_reviews.title: Very happy with it
customer_reviews.text: Very well made and heavy duty. I researched quite a few presses and this one is well worth the price and is built to last. Very happy with it!
customer_reviews.author: Lisa Bright

customer_reviews.title: This is garbage. I would give this zero stars
customer_reviews.text: The handle broke in half (the metal failed, not the hinge) the second time I used it. Not cast iron. Not worth it. I am a chef by trade. This is garbage. I would give this zero stars.
customer_reviews.author: Bubbles

customer_reviews.title: I made thin rotis/tortillas with this baby!
customer_reviews.text: OK, I made rotis/tortillas with this baby. Thin ones! The trick: press several together separated by plastic or parchment. I take each ball and do an initial press for each separately. Then every on top of each other, press. Change order (flip), press. Then the middle one gets put on the bottom, press. Viola! done. 15 seconds. 3 thin rotis/tortillas! These are soft. The ones I roll out are usually tough and chewy. I like the soft ones, yummy - I am so thrilled. Please please everyone try this - quality of life just went up. The only issues is peeling them off when they are so thin. But I grease the plastic/parchment and flour the dough liberally.
customer_reviews.author: farout

customer_reviews.title: Broke during first use
customer_reviews.text: If you are looking to put a lot of weight on the press handle in order to get really thin tortillas, go with something else. I snapped the handle in two during first use. And I wasn't really pressing down with my full weight.
customer_reviews.author: Redlegdonny

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for Indian flat bread bhakri but not for roti
customer_reviews.text: Perfect for making Indian flat bread bhakri. Any dough which is prepared by mixing flour with hot water can be pressed using this tool. I won't recommend this for rotis. Rotis were thick and looked more like puri.
customer_reviews.author: Vaishali

customer_reviews.title: nicely pressed tortilla/roti- in vain
customer_reviews.text: So was very hopeful that after buying this I will be able to make more Rotis( Whole Wheat Tortillas- Indian version :)) every single day. Returned this exactly after a week because no amount of priming, parchment paper, flour, cling wrap, oil helped me with the flattened out dough that would stick and / not be pressed fully! I tried taking bigger portions, small portions, tried different consistencies to get that perfectly flat, nicely pressed tortilla/roti- in vain. At the price point, definitely was not going to keep it!
customer_reviews.author: suave

customer_reviews.title: Solid.
customer_reviews.text: Unfortunately I can't compare this to other tortilla presses, as this is the first one I've ever owned. It does what it's supposed to do; sometimes I do rotate the tortilla 180° to even the thickness out a bit. After reading the reviews here & seeing some worrisome photos, I knew to be wary of the amount of pressure being used on the handle. As warned, it's a good idea to dry the cast iron ASAP after washing. Rust forms easily. Otherwise it's a great size. You can make tortillas of varying sizes. I love making small corn tortillas and sharing the fondness w/ friends. Tacos make the world go round, yo.
customer_reviews.author: Kimberly

customer_reviews.title: Warranty is good.
customer_reviews.text: Broke after only a few uses. As others have noted it is heavy and gives the impression of lasting for generations. It does make thick a tortilla! If you try to press hard it will simply break. Edit revision - After seeing my negative review, I was offered a replacement by the company. I'm therefore revising my review to reflect that even if you encounter problems the company is proven to stand behind their product and make it right. Buy with confidence. Once you have fresh, homemade tortillas eating store bought truly seems like an abomination.
customer_reviews.author: MrMostly

customer_reviews.title: I need more practice
customer_reviews.text: The press itself is nice. Very sturdy construction and simple to put together. Making the tortillas is the tough part, for me. Tons of simple recipes online for making them. I tried the plastic sandwich bag cut to cover each half of the press--upper and lower. I had better success using parchment paper sprayed with your oil of choice. Making the tortillas looks A L-O-T easier on the TV shows but once I got the hang of it the quality and taste was much MUCH better than anything you can buy. Even my failures were good for taco salad or chili. Pati's Mexican Table web site has great recipes for corn and flour tortillas. (No relation, just a fan.)
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Received Today, Already Rusting
customer_reviews.text: I just received it today and I cleaned it and dried it like they recommended before first time use. But within a few hours, it developed rust spots - ugh! It shouldn't have gotten rusty so quickly. It's such a hassle to return stuff right now since we're on COVID-19 quarantine. For now, I'll clean it off and rub some oil on it and HOPE that does the trick. But I am disappointed in spending so much on a "good quality" tortilla press ... Just to have it already rusting -_-
customer_reviews.author: Irene Molina

customer_reviews.title: Great customer service from manufacturer
customer_reviews.text: This product worked great the first 2-3 times we used it to make tortillas, but this last time the round cast iron plate cracked in half. I was surprised that cast iron would break so easily which makes me think it must have had a manufacturing defect. I contacted the company Victoria to file warranty claim and will update this review when I hear back from them. UPDATE: I contacted the manufacturer and they promptly shipped me a replacement the next day. Excellent customer service!
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Great product!
customer_reviews.text: Works great for pressing tortillas and flatbread. Use a split open plastic freezer bag not wax paper. I'd buy it again!
customer_reviews.author: Robert D. Levin

customer_reviews.title: Imitation Victoria cast iron.
customer_reviews.text: I have a great Victoria tortilla press that I’ve used for years and decided to buy one as a gift for my daughter. The tortilla press she received was a cheap imitation called Alpha Living that is not even traditional cast iron. It’s steel that has been painted black, it was gouged, chipped and flaking when she opened the box. Needless to say it is being returned but because it’s heavy shipping will be expensive. Do not buy this unless the seller can guarantee quality and offer free returns.
customer_reviews.author: Celina G Einig

customer_reviews.title: Works but rust and is heavy
customer_reviews.text: Works well but rusted within a week even after seasoning and using parchment paper. Its heavy!!!! But makes perfect taco size tortilla not the dinky ones you find in the store now a day. Making your own tortilla are worth the effort but they don't keep so only make what you will eat that day. I add lime zest and juice to my masa for added flavor
customer_reviews.author: Kevin

customer_reviews.title: Handle Pin Bends/breaks EASILY
customer_reviews.text: Used for very first time and already the handle pin has bent after the first few tortillas - not pressing down hard at all, as I had read reviews about the pin. Still shocked that it bent so easily. I understand why there was a second one provided - but it's surely not going to last. They need to either provide you a baggie full, or how about ONE that actually is strong and works. As for the press.... it was so-so. Being so fearful of bending the pin, we applied NO pressure. The weight of the lid pressed the tortilla down 'ok' and then I hand rolled to desired thinness. Disappointed. Good heavy cast iron.... cheap bendy handle pin.
customer_reviews.author: G.A. Christian

customer_reviews.title: Not durable
customer_reviews.text: I've only used this a few times - I usually roll out my tortillas. The bottom plate literally broke in half. It's a cheap metal, not meant to actually be used.
customer_reviews.author: Katharine Sodergreen

customer_reviews.title: Great product
customer_reviews.text: We use Cassava flour, and were making our tortillas by hand, until we found this! We love it! They come out perfect every time! Definitely recommend!
customer_reviews.author: Danielle Salafrio

customer_reviews.title: This is a replacment unit.
customer_reviews.text: While the handle broke on the first unit I received, I contacted them about the break and I was sent a complete and new unit. I was only looking for a replacement handle but I was sent a new one. It works great and I hope that this handle lasts I like the way it makes tortillas. THANK YOU for the replacement!!! I like the way this made tortilla's and was looking forward to using over and over again, BUT the handle BROKE on the second use. This is a defect in the product and I am hopeful that Victoria Cast Iron will replace it...
customer_reviews.author: S. A Cross

customer_reviews.title: Best Tortilla Press Ever
customer_reviews.text: Tortilla press obviously works for other types of flat bread, not just tortillas, but we used it for corn tortillas. It was pretty much ready to use right out of the box. We attached the handle, wiped it down and then pressed a batch of 12 corn tortillas to be frozen. It was quick and efficient. Extremely high quality for the purchase price! I can already tell it will last a long time. Highly recommend this specific tortilla press to anyone curious about replacing an old one or trying to make homemade flatbreads at home.
customer_reviews.author: Don't Be Alarmed. We Share This Account. 🤣

customer_reviews.title: worked a few times before mine broke
customer_reviews.text: glad the little iron shrapnels didn't take my eye out, our press only worked for a couple times then the press handle snapped in half on me now i have a broken tortilla press i can't return or do anything with. I recommend looking at other presses before buying this one lest you get one and have it break on you AFTER the return date and wind up with a broken $25 press. P.S. why would they even sell 3 year protection for a additional $5.60? it should be lifetime guaranteed just because its a iron cast skillet i mean what are people trying screw buisnesses out of tortilla presses now??.
customer_reviews.author: Dan

customer_reviews.title: WORKS
customer_reviews.text: This definitely works. I actually use it for gluten free, vegan free tortillas but if you have gluten or even eggs it will be even easier to operate. Use two pieces of wax paper to put a ball of dough in between (put the ball closer to the hinge side as it pushes it towards the opening). Just pull your handle down, sometimes you may have to push a little bit harder but usually its pretty easy. Some might say the handle will break and maybe it could but I haven't been close to that yet. Just don't push crazy hard. Sometimes I use a cut open plastic baggy if I run out of wax paper.
customer_reviews.author: KD

customer_reviews.title: Better for corn tortillas
customer_reviews.text: This is really well made, sturdy, & easy to use. I wanted it to make flour tortillas & I think a rolling pin works better for them. I couldn't get them as thin as I would have liked. I think it would work better for corn tortillas. This is why I gave it 4 stars overall.
customer_reviews.author: Lola M

customer_reviews.title: Broken handle.
customer_reviews.text: I was hesitant to purchase this because it has a cast iron handle. Cast iron is fragile and can brake easily. Sure enough it arrived with a broken handle. This seams to be a common problem.
customer_reviews.author: Line Runner

customer_reviews.title: Works very good!
customer_reviews.text: We received it today and made awesome gluten-free tortillas using Cassava flour (not cassava starch,just recently realized there is a difference) and was very happy to see that the press worked very well. It comes with an extra rivet and cotter pin but this extra one is defective. The pin does will not go through the hole in the rivet. So if the seller sees this review please send me a good pin. :)
customer_reviews.author: Sally

customer_reviews.title: Sturdy, but can't make flour tortillas
customer_reviews.text: The tortilla press seems sturdy, and it didn't feel like it was in danger of snapping (I applied an ample amount of pressure). Unfortunately, the tortilla press is unable to press dough thin enough to make a proper flour tortilla. Sure, it works just fine with masa for corn tortillas, but the press is unable to squeeze the tougher flour dough into a tortilla thin enough suitable for tacos. Very disappointing.
customer_reviews.author: Mountain Fresh

customer_reviews.title: Company that makes this tortilla press is awesome!
customer_reviews.text: This tortilla press worked great, but the company that makes it is even better! After using it 3 times the handle broke. I emailed the comapny to ask about getting a replacement handle. I was asked to submit a shipping address, and received a replacement handle in the mail along with a canvas tote free of charge. I was told that sometimes the product can get get damaged during shipping. Regardless of the reason, I was able to get the damaged part replaced with little fuss. Very pleased!
customer_reviews.author: Colleen Baten

customer_reviews.title: Handle broken on arrival.
customer_reviews.text: The handle didn't survive shipping. For real. All those reviews cautioning how weak the handle is... well, trust them. What a disappointment. Would have ruined a birthday dinner if we hadn't had some think books to stand on and a rolling pin. We're just going to go with that now.
customer_reviews.author: Bradley P.

customer_reviews.title: Best Tortilla Press!
customer_reviews.text: Learned how to make tortillas in Yucatan and researched presses. This one is authentic and works perfectly. Do read other reviews for centering balls a little higher to the hinge & experiment, and it will be perfect every time. My Mexican housekeeper was impressed with the press and the tortillas it produced.
customer_reviews.author: fasdjt

customer_reviews.title: Uneven tortillas
customer_reviews.text: I like how sturdy and solid this product is, but each of my tortillas is too thick on one side and almost translucent thin on the other side. This causes me to have to press twice (the second time after rotating the tortilla 180 degrees. After doing so, the tortilla ends up pill-shaped. I can press better, more consistent tortillas with a plate and my body weight, but I wanted to buy something like this to make it easier. It's now easier, but the quality of the press has lowered. Does anyone know a way to make the tortilla more level/less uneven?
customer_reviews.author: Ryan

customer_reviews.title: Can only make bread ~5in in diameter at max force
customer_reviews.text: Buyers: this device has a lever that is not optimized for flat bread over 5 inch.
customer_reviews.author: MITSCIENTIST

customer_reviews.title: Used only a few times, and then the handle ...
customer_reviews.text: Used only a few times, and then the handle snapped. The handle is heavy but it snaps right off. Quite dangerous to use. Debating whether or not to try to get a new handle, since I'm worried that I could hurt myself if I have another handle snap.
customer_reviews.author: David Haley

customer_reviews.title: Handle not so sturdy
customer_reviews.text: I loved this product but the handle snapped after only six months. I only make tortillas a couple of times a month and it wasn't used at all in June or July. So basically I got 4 good months out of this product and it was used less than a dozen times.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Great customer service
customer_reviews.text: I was really impressed with this tortilla press, and used it for about two years before the base cracked in half. I have to say I was surprised, I always thought the obvious point of failure was the handle pin not the solid cast iron base. I had to remove a star because of it breaking, but when I contacted Victoria Cookware they offered to send me a new one immediately. I was very impressed with their customer service, and hopefully the new press will last longer.
customer_reviews.author: JP

customer_reviews.title: Loved the cast iron heavy feel
customer_reviews.text: Loved the cast iron heavy feel. Works great for tortilla. I wish the top plate was as heavy as the bottom plate and the lever did not have a play however. But well - it works for making tortilla. Use plastic sandwich bag or parchment paper and it is even easier. Thanks
customer_reviews.author: SANDEEP S PATWARDHAN

customer_reviews.title: Love it!
customer_reviews.text: Not sure how people are breaking their handles, but so far, I've made over 100 tortillas and no issues. I do like how the instructions recommend using a baggie, which i did for corn tortillas, and had zero issues with tortillas sticking. when making flower tortillas make sure to use a lot of flower on the press, or use wax paper. I didn't like parchment paper at all.
customer_reviews.author: M. Hernandez

customer_reviews.title: So Fun and Simple to Make My Own!
customer_reviews.text: I recently had some issues that led me to believe I have problems with food additives, and they are in almost everything. So I have had to make my own to avoid them. I was so surprise at how fun and simple it is to make my own Tortilla. Makes taco night more an event. I had researched quite a few blogs on which one to get and this one kept coming up. It worked perfectly for me. I like the size and the thickness of the resulting tortillas. It is a heavy press so I was so pleased I did not have to pay the shipping cost. Very happy with my selection.
customer_reviews.author: Janiene

customer_reviews.title: What a disappointment
customer_reviews.text: Being tired of hand rolling my tortillas I decided it was time to splurge for a uniTasker. It works great.... As the paperweight window propper open device it's being used as. Tortillas made with it are 1-4"-1/2" thick (before cooking) and 3-4" in diameter. After cooking it might as well be a slice of bread. It just won't flatten the dough. Save your cash for something useable like a broken vacuum or rusted iron pan, unless you really need a bulky doorstop there are sure to be better options.
customer_reviews.author: Michelle Clary

customer_reviews.title: Heavy duty help in making tortillas
customer_reviews.text: This is no lightweight, and that's a good thing. You can put some real strength behind the press without concern you might bend or break it. We've had consistent success in making thin, flat, even tortillas. This model make smallish tortillas, but that's what we happen to like. If you're new to using a tortilla press, I'd recommend looking for a how-to video on YouTube to help you get started. There are lots of little tips and tricks available to make the job easier and more successful.
customer_reviews.author: Spencer Thomas

customer_reviews.title: I read the reviews and they were good enough for me to buy
customer_reviews.text: I read the reviews and they were good enough for me to buy. I like the product but the handle broke our first time using. I think the alignment of the handle to the disk is not centered correctly. I wish it could be returned but it doesn't look like they give you any way to do that.
customer_reviews.author: Ingrid Clark

customer_reviews.title: Great tortilla press
customer_reviews.text: Love it! Home made tortillas - so worth the effort. Well made, heavy cast iron press and works beautifully. This press makes perfect tortillas every time. From the first use it worked beautifully. I will never buy another store bought tortilla again. This press, a little time, high quality masa harina and you have magic.
customer_reviews.author: Cosmos

customer_reviews.title: Nice small tortilla press, good quality
customer_reviews.text: Nice heavy cast iron press. Directions are straight forward and recommend using wax paper to avoid tortillas sticking to the press. This is great for smaller tortillas used for taquitos or enchiladas. You can punch them out super fast! Was hoping this press was big enough to make burrito sized tortillas, but its too small.
customer_reviews.author: Katy

customer_reviews.title: Qaulity built to last.
customer_reviews.text: I Love this press. I have a norpro one and it is just too flimsy and light. Never liked using it. This one has the right amount of weight to it so it makes pressing easy. Cut a zip lock bag to the size of the circle and put that down then the dough then the other half on top, makes it super simple to peel the tortilla from the ziplog bag. I made a Keto Tortilla and kicked up the flavor with some garlic seasoning and chili lime seasoning.. damn good.
customer_reviews.author: vito

customer_reviews.title: Fantastic press
customer_reviews.text: This press is amazing! It makes corn tortillas so easy! You don't have to push down hard -- the one time I tried it made part of the tortilla too thin. Using this is so much quicker than rolling them out or trying to press them with a flat surface and a weight. Came with instructions and a spare rivet and cotter pin for the handle. I chose to use pre-cut parchment paper for my tortillas and they worked beautifully.
customer_reviews.author: Liv

customer_reviews.title: Good product
customer_reviews.text: This thing does exactly what it's supposed to do. People who have problems with broken hinges or handles are probably exerting considerable force when trying to flatten something. The press isn't built for that. Gentle pressure is plenty. And cleanup isn't a problem because a couple of sheets of waxed paper, parchment paper, or cut plastic bag should be used on top and below the dough or plantain to be flattened, keeping the press itself clean. I think I'll be using this thing quite a bit for making tortillas, tostones, might even--gently--see how it does on smashburger patties.
customer_reviews.author: Mike Hopping

customer_reviews.title: Super disappointed.
customer_reviews.text: Am in the process of returning. Product came rusted over 80% of the item, and was missing the hinge pin for the handle. Super disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: Komski

customer_reviews.title: Useless. I read all the reviews and followed their ...
customer_reviews.text: Useless. I read all the reviews and followed their instructions on how to use. Did not work for me as it would constantly stick to the plates inspite of using Ziploc, flour etc. Just occupies space in my kitchen.
customer_reviews.author: Lotus

customer_reviews.title: Heavy Duty Tortilla Press
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for our Feliz Navidad-themed taco party and it was a life saver. I'm obsessed. It worked really well for our handmade flour tortillas, and I suspect it will be brilliant for corn tortillas. It's heavy duty and I have no fear of it breaking. I bought another for my mom (who, of course already had a cast iron tortilla press, so now I have 2). I highly recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Sarah Byrnes

customer_reviews.title: This Press Is A Beast!
customer_reviews.text: I received my tortilla press today. When I opened the box I had to laugh, thinking about the reviews here that commented on a broken handle. This thing is a beast! There is as much chance of breaking the handle on it as there is breaking the handle on my pre-Depression era #8 cast iron skillet. Possible, but it would require considerable effort. Super impressed by the quality of the cast iron. More than adequate for pressing tortillas.
customer_reviews.author: BLS

customer_reviews.title: Sturdy and does the job
customer_reviews.text: This has upped my Mexican cooking game, there is nothing better than a fresh tortilla. Now I feel far more excited about my dishes because I'm responsible for every flavor and don't have to gamble on what store bought tortillas will taste like. Some masa, some water, salt, and voila! you've got amazing corn tortillas your guests will have about.
customer_reviews.author: Rye Bread

customer_reviews.title: Perfect Tortillas
customer_reviews.text: This is my new favorite kitchen toy. I tried making tortillas by hand. They weren't pretty. This tortilla maker, makes them perfect every time. I am very happy with it. One of the suggestions was to use a ziploc bag to help the tortillas to spread evenly. It works perfect there is no cleanup of the press required afterward.
customer_reviews.author: Daniel Langdon

customer_reviews.title: Quality piece for my low carb tortillas
customer_reviews.text: I bought this tortilla press to make keto/low carb tortillas and have enjoyed it so much. It is the real deal. It is heavy duty and easy to keep clean if you put down parchment paper or a sandwich bag cut up. I expect this to last my lifetime and then some. BTW, my tortilla recipe is basically the Fat Head Pizza Dough recipe made with Miracle Mix from Wellness Bakeries instead of straight almond flour. They are delicious! This press has made it possible to turn my tortillas into mini pie crusts as well, by just pressing them into silicone baking cups. I am so thrilled with it!
customer_reviews.author: 21 Days

customer_reviews.title: It works !
customer_reviews.text: I bought this to have a healthier alternative. So I have experimented some mixing different flours. Your corn and straight up flour ones will taste the best but, I do mix wheat, coconut, almond and walnut flour in at times as well. A plastic bag is key when pressing out. And then only a minute or two in the pan. You make a lot in a short time if your ready to go. It will save you money with healthier options. Good luck
customer_reviews.author: JT

customer_reviews.title: Tortilla press
customer_reviews.text: This thing is heavy and does its job really well. I got a pack of parchment paper circles that I use plus a little cooking spray, and that keeps everything moving very well.
customer_reviews.author: N. Gailey

customer_reviews.title: great product, check tip/ trick.
customer_reviews.text: I wanted a larger square model similar to one a saw a Mexican woman using in Mexico, but this works just fine. I mimicked her technique of moving the handle side to side while pressing and the tortillas come out fine. 8" is large enough and the fresh product is well liked at home. How anyone could break the handle I don't know, no strength is required beyond that of an 8 year old girl. The trick is to use a plastic produce bag on both sides of the dough. Just cut the bag with scissors, half is enough. While I did not get out my calipers to measure, thickness was fine.
customer_reviews.author: WARD

customer_reviews.title: No happy with my purchase
customer_reviews.text: So disappointed, I purchased my husband a tortilla press by Victoria when he opened the box it was rusted. The box had no indication the product was damaged.
customer_reviews.author: mommy owl

customer_reviews.title: STAY AWAY from this garbage product!!!!
customer_reviews.text: Handle broke off with the first use! Terrible product. Such a complete waste of money and didn't even make them flat in the first place. If you have to finish with a roller, you might as well start with one.
customer_reviews.author: Rantire

customer_reviews.title: So good! Worked perfectly for my fajitas
customer_reviews.text: I just used this for the first time last week. Not gonna lie....I had a hard time figuring out how to set it up as there were no instructions. I looked at other people's pictures online to figure out what they did and saved the pieces that were extra in a labeled ziploc bag. I followed advice and cut up a gallon sized ziploc bag to place my dough ball on. I was able to crank out tortillas in a few minutes. Love this and will likly not buy store bought tortillas again. Thank you
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Works well and is a good price for it's quality.
customer_reviews.text: This makes my gluten free food MUCH easier to make! I misjudged and def should have gotten a bigger one for my burritos but I figured out a bit of a hack to make a little bigger. Love that this is cast iron! It seems sturdy bit also kinda feels like too much pressure could break it. I'm glad I got this and it def makes taco night easier and quicker.
customer_reviews.author: Nihx Knows

customer_reviews.title: Excellent product
customer_reviews.text: When I received this product, it was dirty and had already been used. I cleaned it up though and it works great now. It is a little difficult to maintain, due to the cast iron, however it is well worth it. Very heavy, easy to use, and makes perfectly thin tortilla.
customer_reviews.author: Sarah B.

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use and you get good results
customer_reviews.text: I make plantain wraps with it. Once you get a feel for it, you can get a uniform thickness (don't push it ALL the way down). I use mine with parchment paper, so I never have to wash it. All it gets on it is a bit of grease that penetrates the parchment paper, and you want that on cast iron anyway.
customer_reviews.author: R. Herman

customer_reviews.title: Useless.
customer_reviews.text: Worthless if you ask me. First off, the handle is just asking to be broken with too much pressure, although it can take a lot. One. Two, the tamales don't expand as big as the press so you still end up taking them off and rolling them with a wooden roller. I just don't see the point of this thing. I wish I would have spent more on a wooden press.
customer_reviews.author: Jibberish18

customer_reviews.title: love this press already!
customer_reviews.text: I just got this press an hour ago. It's wrapped well and was in perfect condition. It's heavy and pretty well made. I washed it well and dried it, per instructions. I mixed up a batch of masa harina and am happy to say that it pressed the dough perfectly. It's easy to use and quickly presses the dough. I didn't have to use much pressure at all, barely coaxing the hand down. For less than $20., this press is impressive!!
customer_reviews.author: Not available

customer_reviews.title: Super solid and easy to use!
customer_reviews.text: So fun to make tortillas with this press! Definitely takes some getting used to — my first time making them, trying to get the dough the right consistency is the most challenging part. Sometimes plastic ziplock bags work as top and bottom of tortillas, sometimes parchment paper works better. But this press is awesome for making taco-sized shells.
customer_reviews.author: Cathie

customer_reviews.title: handle is fine
customer_reviews.text: I have had no problems with this tortilla press. the weight of the press is heavy enough where you don't need to be putting too much pressure. I think the people that are snapping the handle are putting their weight on it, which, I don't think is necessary. The pin that they give you to connect the handle is a bit clunky and gets in the way a little, but it's not a deal breaker by any means. would not hesitate to buy again.
customer_reviews.author: Peter

customer_reviews.title: This is a great press
customer_reviews.text: I bought it based on the reviews, and chose not to go with a light weight press. This works well and as described, and am very happy. No complaints and no issues with any breakage. I think people are pressing too hard, if their handles are snapping off.
customer_reviews.author: Jessica Eiss

customer_reviews.title: Good stuff
customer_reviews.text: I've always wanted one of these and I finally got one. 1. Let me just say Amazon was great about quickly replacing the one the delivery guy misplaced. 2. This is the best thing in the world for pursuing tortillas. I've only had it for maybe a month and have used it 3 or 4 times. 3. I haven't had any of the other problems people talk about with the peeling or fragility of the item. It seems pretty strong to me. Pretty satisfied.
customer_reviews.author: Leah

customer_reviews.title: I love this press!
customer_reviews.text: I love this press. It beats rolling out each tortilla by hand. I whipped out 14 tortillas in 14 mins. I did not use ziploc bag as the instructions recommends, I used parchment paper. I had two separate pieces of parchment, placed dough ball between the two then pressed. Took the tortilla (parchment and all) set in hot cast iron fry pan for 15 secs, turned over for another 15 secs and so on until the paper come off easily then finished cooking. I used the same parchment paper for the entire process. Put parchment paper between each tortilla so they wouldn’t stick to each other. Hubby had a fresh warm tortilla with cheese, he raves about them.
customer_reviews.author: J. M. Ayers

customer_reviews.title: Together with learning to make Masa this is a great tool to make tortillas your way
customer_reviews.text: I'm an engineer with a Taco habit. Could not help myself and needed to know how tacos are made - by making them myself. The Victoria was my introduction to a tortilla press and making my own tortillas. Works well, not fussy, and well made. So far successfully made over 300 tortillias with this press and works well. Together with learning to make Masa this is a great tool to make tortillas your way! Needless to say, can't go back to store bought tortillas.
customer_reviews.author: Great!

customer_reviews.title: Amazing press
customer_reviews.text: I bought this tortilla press as a gift for my husband (we were previously using a no name metal press). This sturdy cast iron press immediately out shown the other. The arm of the other press would bend under pressure and leave the tortilla too thick, but our new Victoria cast iron press gets the job done! Go ahead, buy it! It’s worth it.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Works very well with no effort required
customer_reviews.text: This tortilla press works extremely well. I used Maceca and followed the directions on the bag, with a couple of exceptions. I added a few drops of canola oil and let it rest about 20 minutes. The dough was soft and pliable. It took no effort at all to press the tortillas. I found a 30 gram ball of dough formed the size and thickness tortilla I was looking for. Most of the forming was done by the weight of the top plate with only a gentle press of the handle to finish forming. Very satisfied.
customer_reviews.author: KeithG

customer_reviews.title: What the heck?
customer_reviews.text: Mine snapped in half the first day. Not the joint...the actual bottom plate snapped in half. I’m simply not strong enough to snap cast iron, so I’m wondering if it’s an alloy.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Use wax paper around the dough and it works pretty well. You can get an uneven tortilla if ...
customer_reviews.text: Use wax paper around the dough and it works pretty well. You can get an uneven tortilla if you press too hard - wish there was a stop or something when it was pressed to even. But I've done about 4 batches so far and I find it works good. Tip: I put little cork feet under it to keep from scratching my countertop.
customer_reviews.author: Jeff T.

customer_reviews.title: Use a rolling pin
customer_reviews.text: This thing sucks. No matter how hard or the number of times I pressed, the tortillas were too thick. Granted, I made flour tortillas. One reviewer stated this product was meant for corn tortillas. Some reviewers stated the handle breaks easy. I did not find this to be the case. I put a lot of pressure on it as well. I would return it but I'm sure the cost of shipping would eat up the refund. Better to to just use a rolling pin.
customer_reviews.author: Poo Tinky

customer_reviews.title: Gift from the gods!!
customer_reviews.text: Searched all over amazon and google to find the best reviewed press.. I found it here!! Amazing press!! I made tortillas and tamales on it and it made my life so much easier... wish it was 10” instead of 8” but it gets the job done!!
customer_reviews.author: Jessica Marie

customer_reviews.title: Easy to work, but heavy to lift
customer_reviews.text: It is heavy and sturdy. If it ever fails, it will be at "the pin" (clip) which holds the handle on. That must be why they send an extra pin. Use pliers to bend the pin down once you are certain you have it put together correctly. It works well, but you need to put plastic or parchment down before pressing tortillas. I wish it came with that information and a good recipe for tortillas. It is heavier than I thought. The handle is too long. It takes a lot of space. I wish I had bought an electric press that presses and cooks.
customer_reviews.author: Psyohe

customer_reviews.title: Works great but becareful with the handle at full "open" position
customer_reviews.text: Works great but becareful with the handle at full "open" position. It is heavy and can swing and hit the counter top causing damages to the tile surface. They need to put an stopper there.
customer_reviews.author: b555

customer_reviews.title: Great Kitchen tool!
customer_reviews.text: Lovely people to deal with. Company is in Colombia South America and we corresponded with them to learn when they would commence shipping again during covid. Love the product. It looks like it will be with us for life: sturdy construction, ease of use, fun to use. There is nothing like a home made tortilla! Yum! Highly recommend this product.
customer_reviews.author: flowers

customer_reviews.title: The dough sticks quite a bit
customer_reviews.text: I was so excited when I got this as i hoped I can make tortillas and rotis very quickly but I am a bit disappointed so far because the dough sticks and not able to make it as I expected. The material itself is quite sturdy and the mechanism is simple and clean. The surface is not entirely smooth and I see it’s rough so not sure if that’s causing the dough to break. Will have to try few more times with different proportions but I expected to work well without much of tinkering on my part
customer_reviews.author: Balaji Natarajan

customer_reviews.title: Awesome corn tortillas!
customer_reviews.text: I haven’t made flour tortillas yet, but the corn tortillas turn out perfectly round. You can vary the thickness depending how you press the lever. (Someone talkeD about adding 50 pages of paper, which would produce a crepe!) someone else taled about quality of lever, but it is rock solid. My only suggestion for the company would be to make a 12” size. (I like large flour ones...)
customer_reviews.author: ScubaDeb

customer_reviews.title: Good investment, durable, well made, will last. Heavy.
customer_reviews.text: It's durable. It's going to last. It's well made. It does the job. It's also heavy which is annoying for me with back problems, however, do not get the lighter metal (aluminum) kind because you'll have to apply more pressure, more work to get the job done. It's just too flimsy, too light weight. That's too much work. This heavy cast iron type one WILL get the job done and shouldn't die on you for a long time. It's a good investment. It doesn't need that much pressure by YOU to flatten your tortillas.
customer_reviews.author: Marie 1.

customer_reviews.title: What can go wrong with good old cast iron
customer_reviews.text: What can go wrong with good old cast iron. This little machine is heavy and does the trick. My husband made sausage rolls and used this the flatten the pizza dough. PERFECT. I made flat bread with whole wheat flour and that was a little challenging for me until I realized it was not the machine, but my strength, which my husband has to he can flatten them. Saves a lot of time.
customer_reviews.author: jd114

customer_reviews.title: Great tortilla press. Sure beats rolling out between parchment paper. Perfect every time.
customer_reviews.text: Great tortilla press. Sure beats rolling out between parchment paper. Perfect every time. Best to cut a sandwich zipper type bag so you can put your dough ball between the two plastic pieces. This will keep the dough from sticking to the press. To press into a round tortilla, press the handle lightly and rotate. Others have stated that the handle would break if pressing too hard. One doesn’t need to press hard in order to make a perfect, thin tortilla. I personally use it to make my KETO tortillas. Perfect every time! Enjoy!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: So easy to use!
customer_reviews.text: Gave this a couple months of use before reviewing it! My boyfriend is a cook and we were recently watching the Chef’s Table on Enrique Olvera when he could not stop mentioning how much he wanted to try to make homemade tortillas. As soon as we finished the episode, I hopped on Amazon to order him this press as an early Christmas gift. He loves it! Not only is it super easy to use but we’ve used it pretty regularly since getting it (at least once a week) and haven’t had a single issue yet. If you’re thinking about it, get it. You’ll ask yourself why you ever bothered using store bought tortillas in the first place.
customer_reviews.author: Michele Sinfield

customer_reviews.title: Fresh tortillas are so incredibly easy
customer_reviews.text: Buy this!!! I don’t know why we have been buying tortillas at the store our whole lives. They are so easy to make with this press and so incredibly delicious. One of my favorite kitchen gadgets! I wrap parchment paper around the top & bottom when using and the tortillas don’t stick. When finished, I remove the paper and let the press air dry on the counter (as any moisture will cause rust). Small enough to store in a cabinet. Excellent purchase!
customer_reviews.author: JM Cruz

customer_reviews.title: It works well!
customer_reviews.text: This tortilla press is really heavy and sturdy. It does a great job pressing dough for tortillas. Just be careful about drying it thoroughly after use. I left it wet for about an hour and it started developing rust immediately. It is made of cast iron, so it’s expected. Oil it a little after drying well and it should keep clean of rust.
customer_reviews.author: Gab

customer_reviews.title: Fastest, easiest way to a thin flat disc
customer_reviews.text: This press does just what it’s supposed to. Easily made my keto dough into a thin, flat, round disc. Parchment paper on top and bottom of food assures no sticking and no need to wash the press. Heavy duty !
customer_reviews.author: Vicki

customer_reviews.title: Good purchase
customer_reviews.text: I have always wanted to get one. For what I was not sure. I did not use it right after I got it. The other day I tried making chinese scallion pancakes with it and made it easier. I’m not great with rolling pins. I then tried it to make dumplings skins and it was easier too. Need to use baking sheet between the dough and the press so it won’t stick and easy to clean. Next I’m going to try making tortillas, what it’s intended to be used for.
customer_reviews.author: Minnatabo

customer_reviews.title: Buy this one.
customer_reviews.text: Buy this one. Dont be fooled into buying a different press. I was fooled by another press and spent $25 on one and the very day i received it i went back to amazon and bought this one. The other press is a paper weight. If you want easy, even, tortillas this is all you need and if its out of stock just buy it and wait, it will come.
customer_reviews.author: Erin cyfers

customer_reviews.title: Makes thick tortillas and broke within months
customer_reviews.text: This tortilla press does not make thin tortillas as others have noted. You will still need a rolling pin later. Nevertheless I used it for about 3 months because it helped a little. But after three months I was pressing a tortilla and suddenly it cracked. Initially I thought the handle broke because it did seem vulnerable but I was wrong. The entire cast iron base broke in half (see pictures). Now it is unusable and I had to throw it because I’m outside the return window. I don’t know who other tortilla press is better but my recommendation is to just use a good old rolling pin.
customer_reviews.author: Dan

customer_reviews.title: Works good
customer_reviews.text: I got tired of using a rolling pin for corn tortillas, so I got this. Pressed too hard the first time and the too thin dough stuck on the plastic bag that I lined it with. But the 2nd press and after came out almost perfect. Cut up a ziploc bag to line the press for easy cleanup and use. It's heavy and the handle seems very sturdy. Don't press too hard.
customer_reviews.author: Sedgwint

product_meta.title: Victoria 8 Inch Cast Iron Tortilla Press. Tortilla Maker, Flour Tortilla press, Rotis Press, Dough Press, Pataconera Seasoned with Flaxeed Oil, Black -
product_meta.description: Size:8"Size 8 inch For over 75 years Victoria has been perfecting the art of smart design in cast iron cookware Finding the perfect balance between tradition & innovation Make perfectly natural flat and consistently thin tortillas with the internationally known Victoria cast iron tortilla press The heavyweight construction means less effort and more consistency when pressing This is the real deal Say goodbye to store-bought tortillas (who knows what they even put in those) and hello to fun fresh and healthy tortillas! This easy press is also known as a pataconera and is great as a tortilla maker patacones maker to St ones Quesadilla maker Chapatti maker Roti maker empanadas arepas and more Yes it's even strong enough for fried plantain tombstones!
feature_bullets: ✔️ DO it yourself. Make your own tortillas, patacones, Rotis, empanadas, quesadillas, and Arepas at home fast and easy. Great for non-gluten and Paleo tortillas too!
✔️ Reinforced Design. We improved the base & the handle for better resistance. Our cast iron plates are engineered to avoid pinching. Get even tortillas every time.
✔️ Heavy-duty construction. Made of cast-iron seasoned at high temperatures with 100% non-GMO vegetable flaxseed oil. Low maintenance. Restaurant quality.
✔️ Comes with an extra screw for the lever. Includes detailed instructions on use and care. Overall width - Side to side: 11. 25 inch, overall depth - front to back: 11 inch
✔️ Authentic by Victoria. Tortilladora made in Colombia since 1986, Don't trust imitators! Limited Lifetime .
